interesting Uh on on Monday like three

whenever it is I'm going to go to DC and
I'm going to testify before Senator
Widen on internet security uh he's
holding hearings on internet security
and I was invited and I've spent the
last week or so thinking you know what
do I want to tell Congress about
internet security You know if I get a a
handful of Congress critters in a room
and I have five minutes to speak to them
what is it that I want to tell them It's
actually an interesting
question Now a lot of what I want to
tell them is stuff I've been saying for
for a while that the internet is no
different than the real world To me one
of the reasons we're doing security so
poorly on the internet is that we think
that somehow because computers are
involved it's magically
different That it's based on technology
and technology can save us somehow and
technology can magically make things
better
Yeah it's turning out not to be true In
in in this talk I would have given I put
up a slide where I say you know computer
security is a 40-year-old academic
discipline Every year there are new
papers new products new
ideas new techniques and every year the
problem gets
worse right We're not it's not that
we're not breaking even you know we're
losing we're losing ground every year uh
someone who spoke here yesterday uh CNET
ran wrote an article on what they said
talking about how the the new viruses
and Trojans that'll happen the next few
years will be significantly worse Now I
thought everything you said made a lot
of sense and that ends up being true for
pretty much everything right Every new
version of Microsoft Windows makes
things worse Every
new and I don't mean to pick on Windows
It's you know they're they're certainly
bad but everything else also makes
things worse It's to me it's all about
complexity I mean last year on this
stage I gave a talk about complexity
being the enemy of
security where my thesis was that as
systems get more complex as they get
more integrated they get less secure And
there's no way to avoid that That is an
inevitable byproduct of
complexity And I believe and I would
want to tell the Congress critters that
the internet is too complex to secure
That if someone gets up on the uh the
podium and testifies I can secure the
internet they're either lying or
delusional That in fact there's no such
thing
Now often when I tell people that they
get very disturbed and say well if you
can't secure the internet what are we
going to
do and this is where I go back to the
real world you know we can't secure the
real world and yet we're all here
enjoying lunch right
we firewalls will never prevent you know
unauthorized network access but that's
okay you can't buy a device that
prevents murder
And that's both surprising disturbing
and and and good I'm losing the positive
word right It's it's true We cannot
prevent murder If someone wants to kill
you they would just kill you Yet we in
our society are safe most of the
time And we're safe not because we go
out and buy body armor
We're safe for a whole lot of other
reasons that don't
involve
prevention And I said this last year
also most computer security to date has
centered around prevention
techniques prophylactics How can I
prevent this from
happening And that's not the way we
approach security safety in the real
world
If you wanted to improve the security of
your house you wouldn't get thicker
walls right That wouldn't be something
that would occur to you Yet if you want
to improve the security of your network
the first thing you think of is how can
I get a thicker firewall How can I get
better
prevention Right I'm going to go to a
few slides I don't I don't know how the
camera is switching
Do slides come up there No Well that's
kind of useless Never mind
then Right So to me computer security
has evolved It's usually the way it's
evolved I came to computer security hey
through through cryptography And
cryptography is neat Cryptography is
mathematics right Security is very much
a function of the
math and and this is the way of thinking
that came from cryptography into
computer security There's a very there's
a notion of absolute security This also
came from the
military right There are threats and you
have to avoid them The threat is
easedropping Cryptography prevents the
threat And it was very simple in the
notion in the time when you had Alice
and Bob communicating by
radio So this idea dovetailed very
nicely with the way we as computer
engineers approach problems Figure out
what the problems are and you solve them
Right If you have a compression problem
you'll apply some compression technology
You have a security problem you apply
Trump security technology
And this is the way we we've been
approaching security The the conceit
here is that technology can solve
computer security and make us secure
somehow The real world has a very
different model when they approach
security They have a riskmanagement
model Right In business there are many
risks Security is one of those risks
Security is very relative Right It's one
of the risks that you need to
manage There are lots of different ways
to manage it It's not just avoid the
threat or not You can manage the risk in
many different ways and you can fail You
know businesses make stupid decisions
all the time It might cost them money It
might cost them share price but for the
most part they can survive
So if you think risk
management and apply that to a security
problem you have a lot of options You
know I like to take a real example Uh
the security problem is shoplifting A
corner store and they're worried about
shoplifting There are a lot of things
you can do You can accept the risk right
If you're a grocery
store you can simply accept the risk of
shoplifting Your merchandise is very
cheap It comes off the top line It's
called shrinkage You're still in
business
You can mitigate the risk with
technology You can put tags on your
garments You could put sensors on the
doors You won't eliminate shoplifting
but you will reduce it and you'll manage
your risk You can manage the risk with
procedures You think of a jewelry store
where the merchandise is under lock and
key where if you want to handle the
merchandise
uh a employee will help you Right This
also mitigates the risk It helps manage
shoplifting and or you could transfer
the risk right That same insurance
company sorry that same jewelry store
will have
insurance There'll be some residual risk
that they're going to pass on to a third
party And actually it'll be some
combination right You know any business
will do some combination of technology
of procedures of
insurance and manage their risk that way
Go to the slide
Yeah And the security they do has to
make business
sense right You can you this is my graph
of of of security You can be on on the
left side have no security and a very
expensive losses due to breaches You
could be on the right side have a lot of
security and no losses due to breaches
Both of which are going to be too
expensive Right In the middle there's
adequate security at a reasonable cost
That's what you're looking for And this
is important Right I can improve the
security at a bank by strip searching
everybody who walks into the branch That
would work but it's bad
business Uh more than half of all
shoplifting in department stores occur
occurs in dressing rooms I can improve
security by removing all the dressing
rooms That would
work right But you can't do that because
it doesn't make business sense
So when when computer security people
make decisions about computer security
they're only seeing half the equation
They're just seeing more or less secure
They're not seeing smarter or dumber
business And I think that's real
important
So once you start thinking about
security in terms of risk management and
once you realize that the technology is
not going to save you you're forced to
ask you know what what will save
you And I mean there there are three
points I want to make One is made in the
talk and two I'm just going to make Uh
the first one is this notion of
prevention detection and response I've
been saying this for a number of
years that in the real world we get
security primarily through detection and
response not through
prevention You know we don't we don't
make thicker walls in our house We put
in an alarm
system right even a bank will have an
alarm and detection and response if it
works well enough makes up for shoddy
prevention Right One of my realities
here is that prevention isn't very
good right You know firewalls have
problems All all security products will
have problems The neat thing about
detection and response is it can make up
for shoddy prevention right If you can
imagine an alarm that's fast enough and
you know guards that respond quick
enough you could dump your money in the
middle of the street and it would be
secure
So I think this is real important that
this this notion of alarms and guards
that we use all through the real world I
mean wander around the casino here and
you know why is this casino secure
Because there are guards because there
are alarms Not because the chips are
under lock and
key I mean a casino is you know a a a
poster child for detection and response
and how to make security that way
So I believe very strongly in monitoring
I have a company that does
monitoring and and to me in a world
that's increasingly complex where the
products are failing you know more and
more drastically that there's not much
else we can do you know we do the best
we can with the products but we need to
have detection and
response So that's thing one Uh thing
two which is actually I'm I'm completely
gone from the talk Uh I believe
insurance will make a great difference
in computer security In the real world
insurance drives
security But if you look up maybe not in
this tent but certainly in a building
you're going to see sprinklers The
reason they're there is not because
Caesar's Palace loves us Insurance and
building codes demand it
Now really since the turn of the century
the insurance industry has
driven what kinds of security you might
have on your warehouse on your building
what kinds of fire prevention you're
going to
have because they will write policies
that depend on what sort of
countermeasures you have Now this is
really interesting and I this is going
to happen in the computers It can't not
But what it will do is it will force
companies to make decisions based on the
security of products Right Right now
there is no benefit for any company to
design a product that's secure Right
Microsoft knows this Right For them to
spend money to make Windows secure is a
waste of money They know it and that's
why they don't bother But if every
company had to have hacking
insurance and their underwriter would
say "Well look here are here's two
policies Here's your policy if you use
Windows Here's your policy if you use
Linux right?" And they cost different
Suddenly it becomes a financial decision
which operating system you use Suddenly
Microsoft loses sales because they are
not as secure as another operating
system Suddenly Microsoft and every
other company has to take security
seriously because they have no
alternative You know I don't see this
happening soon This is probably three to
five years
out But the rise of
litigation and
insurance insuring companies against
losses is going to
force end users to make financial
decisions about the security of
products And I see a big change there
So one of the thing I've been pushing
for is the insurance industry to get
involved in this And we're starting to
see some of this There are companies
offering insurance Uh there are tie-ins
with products There was one company
bless their heart that did offer a
reduction in rates if you use
Linux That was a small company but this
kind of thing is happening You know
right now it's hard We don't have the
actuarial data to really make these
kinds of decisions but that's coming and
that's just a matter of of doing
it The third thing that I guess I I
would want to tell Congress that I think
is going to to help is law
enforcement This is also real important
One of the primary reasons we're safe in
the real world is because we prosecute
criminals
You know if you sort of look at the
difference between the United States and
a you know warlordrun third world
country is that we have a lawful
society And and you can look at
prosecution and uh and conviction and
you know and have lots of philosophical
discussions as as what it means and why
we do it as a society But one of the
benefits it has is it acts as a
deterrence That in fact
if if crime doesn't pay then people are
less likely to do it If you're living in
a society where criminals can operate
with impunity you're more likely to get
a lawless society you know which is what
you might see in a country like Rwanda
which to some extent is what we see on
the internet you know we see uh you know
unskilled script kitties who you know
can break into computers and can cause
damage because they know they're not
going to get caught because they know
they're not going to get
convicted And I I think I think this is
this is a big deal It's hard to do on
the net You know we we all can talk
about the difficulties of of doing
forensics of actually you know tracking
down who the criminals are on the net We
all know the problems but we need to do
more of it And one of the problems I see
uh we have any number of customers that
that we we monitor and defend and we we
can find and stop hacks and we'll ask do
you want to prosecute You know I thought
they would almost invariably they say no
And I think this is also a uh an
artifact of being in a lawless society
right Right If you're if you're in a
society that doesn't operate under the
rule of law you don't want to make waves
You don't want to stand out because
you're afraid of
retribution If you live in a society
where you believe that the
benefits of standing up the benefits of
prosecuting outweigh the negatives
you're more likely to do it So I think
this is this is a scale that's going to
have to tip slowly
Now there's a whole lot of ways to do
prosecution wrong We've we've kind of
sort of seen them all in in the computer
world over the past five six years but
certainly there has to be a way to do
prosecution
right And I think it's real important
that that we figure out how to do
it So those are my three that's now of
course sitting in front of of the Senate
hearing I would have been done 15
minutes ago
They like she they give they they give

five

should be
entertaining But you know if if if I was

that because it's being run on computers

violations Right The internet is
populated by
people And the same techniques that have
worked for thousands of years in the
real world are going to be the same ones
that work on the online
world that really there's no difference
I mean sure there are there are minor
